summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Arizona today entered a final judgment in favor of Arizona resident Ahmad A. Al-Thanayyan in a civil case brought by his wife, Tiffany Lee Lehn, against the family court's order to impose a $2.5 million bond on Father.  The court found that Father violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 ("Securities Act") and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") by improperly allocating community property and debt in violation of those provisions and by failing to properly consider the relative financial resources, Mother's ability to pay her own fees, and Father’s ability to make a reasonable determination of her share of the community interest in the businesses.  In its judgment, the court also ordered that Father be barred from traveling with the children to Kuwait and ordered him to pay $1.2 million in disgorgement and prejudgment interest.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the judgment, Father consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently restrains and enjoins him from violating Section 25(b).  The judgment also orders that he pay a $1,500 civil penalty, a $100,000 officer-and-director bar, and a $20,000 civil penalty.   The settlement is subject to court approval.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Arizona, Father and his wife were married in 2006 and lived there for five years. The court ordered Father to exercise parenting time in Arizona unless Mother agreed to a judgment requiring him to do so.  On the same day, Father petitioned for divorce in Kuwait, which he did not do, and was denied entry to the United States as a result of the court's finding that he had received income from his Kuwaiti businesses for the benefit of the Kuwaiti community.  As alleged in the complaint, Father had told one child to lie to Mother about having a cell phone and had told the child he was old enough to visit Kuwait on his own and “more than that.”  The complaint also alleges that Father had falsely claimed that Mother had left Kuwait without legal justification and submitted a power of attorney stating that he was the natural guardian of the children. The complaint further alleges that the court had no basis for this unequal allocation because the court did not consider Father's claims about his business interests when it imposed the bond.
